docs.lead_paragraph: In June, the Supreme Court will hand down decisions fraught with political implications on same-sex marriage and the Affordable Care Act.

docs.lead_paragraph: Kaiser Permanente and unions representing 105,000 health care workers across the United States have reached a tentative labor agreement.

headline.main: Kaiser Permanente, Workers Reach Tentative Contract Plan
headline.print_headline: Kaiser Permanente, Workers Reach Tentative Contract Plan

docs.snippet: Kaiser Permanente and unions representing 105,000 health care workers across the United States have reached a tentative labor agreement.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Florida doctor accused of giving lavish gifts to U.S. Senator Robert Menendez in a corruption case could soon be freed after a bail hearing Monday where prosecutors asked for bail to be set at $20 million on separate Medicare fraud charges.

headline.main: Florida Doctor Tied to Senator Menendez Corruption Case Awaits Bail
headline.print_headline: Florida Doctor Tied to Senator Menendez Corruption Case Awaits Bail

docs.snippet: A Florida doctor accused of giving lavish gifts to U.S. Senator Robert Menendez in a corruption case could soon be freed after a bail hearing Monday where prosecutors asked for bail to be set at $20 million on separate Medicare fraud charges.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. President Barack Obama said on Monday that he was confident the Supreme Court would not rule against his healthcare law, describing it as an "easy case" that should never have been taken up by the court.

headline.main: Obama: No Reason for Supreme Court to Overturn Healthcare Law
headline.print_headline: Obama: No Reason for Supreme Court to Overturn Healthcare Law

docs.snippet: U.S. President Barack Obama said on Monday that he was confident the Supreme Court would not rule against his healthcare law, describing it as an "easy case" that should never have been taken up by the court.

docs.lead_paragraph: With a crucial legal decision looming, President Barack Obama said Monday the Supreme Court should not even have considered the latest challenge to his signature health care law but he voiced confidence the justices "will play it straight" — and leave the law intact.

headline.main: Obama: Court Shouldn't Have Considered Health Law Challenge
headline.print_headline: Obama: Court Shouldn't Have Considered Health Law Challenge

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S Supreme Court on Monday rejected the state of Maine's bid to revive its plan to trim some young people from its Medicaid rolls.

headline.main: U.S. Justices Reject Maine Challenge to Medicaid Funding
headline.print_headline: U.S. Justices Reject Maine Challenge to Medicaid Funding

docs.snippet: The U.S Supreme Court on Monday rejected the state of Maine's bid to revive its plan to trim some young people from its Medicaid rolls.

docs.lead_paragraph: A man who admitted scheming with his ex-wife in setting a string of arson fires to bilk insurers out of hundreds of thousands of dollars was sentenced Monday to nearly six years in federal prison for his role in a 2001 blaze that killed their teenage son.

headline.main: Man Sentenced to Prison for Arson That Killed Teenage Son
headline.print_headline: Man Sentenced to Prison for Arson That Killed Teenage Son

docs.lead_paragraph: Drought has killed about 12 million trees in California's national forests. In the Rocky Mountain region, an epidemic of pine beetles has damaged trees over a stretch of 32 million acres. Altogether, up to 40 percent of the entire national forest system is in need of treatment to reduce the threat of catastrophic wildfire and disease.

headline.main: Republicans Shift Strategy in Effort to Increase Logging
headline.print_headline: Republicans Shift Strategy in Effort to Increase Logging

docs.lead_paragraph: Only 25 states have passed budgets for the coming year, and many of the bitterest fights are not between the two parties, but between conservative and centrist Republicans.

headline.main: States Confront Wide Budget Gaps Even After Years of Recovery
headline.print_headline: States Confront Cavernous Holes in Their Budgets

docs.abstract: Many states are experiencing budget shortfalls, pitting lawmakers against governors, but most are states with both Republican-controlled legislatures and governors' offices; amidst intense budgets fights between conservative and centrist Republicans, only 25 states have passed spending plans in 2015.
docs.snippet: Only 25 states have passed budgets for the coming year, and many of the bitterest fights are not between the two parties, but between conservative and centrist Republicans.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Jeremy Alford from Baton Rouge, La.; Alan Blinder from Atlanta; Kirk Johnson from Seattle; and John Eligon from Kansas City, Mo.
